text:
How to become a cool designer and learn how to work with client edits
04 Nov 2019, 19:00 by Affiliate Material
The head of the ‚ÄúNetology‚Äù educational direction for designers tells how to choose a design profession, prepare a portfolio and learn how to work with client edits.



Vladimir SinitsynHead of Design and UX at Netologia Online University
‚ÄúTo become a good designer, it‚Äôs better not to be a creative person‚Äù

- What do the employees of the educational direction ‚ÄúDesign and UX‚Äù that you lead in ‚ÄúNetologiya‚Äù do? What are your specific tasks?

- I work as the head of the design department. I create educational programs for people who want to become designers in different areas: web design, game design, motion and many others. Seven other people do these programs with me. The producers are project managers, they follow the general outline. Methodologists communicate with experts and develop content. The facilitators lead students who complete the course and answer all questions.




- How many different professions do the designer have in common today?

- In Netology, we so far highlight four areas on the basis of which we build educational lines. And within the framework of these areas, different professions and more niche specializations are already being formed.

Product design. This is the creation of interfaces that solve business problems. We teach you to research, analyze and find a visual solution that suits the business and solves the needs of the user.
Graphic design and communication. This is a job with marketing: creating a company identity, advertising, corporate identity. Here we give a digital design base, but also tell how to build a brand, choose a slogan, how to pack data into infographics.
Motion design. These are graphics in motion, work with animation. When you need to animate static graphics and integrate it into a video, website or game. For example, replace the background of a video clip or add a flying fly to it.
Game design. Describes the rules and features of the games. Game designers are practically product managers in the gaming industry, often they control the entire process from idea to implementation. Here we teach how to create prototypes of games, game interface templates, explain the mechanics and storytelling.

There are still cross-disciplinary professions, for example, at the intersection of design and programming. Suppose a full ‚Äë stack ‚Äë designer is a universal player. He typeset pages, designs.
You can learn any of these professions. It all depends on the person himself: whether he wants new knowledge or looks at the course as a magic pill. After all, the task of education is to give a system of theory and practice so that a person does not run through disparate information channels, where half of the information is based on personal opinion, rather than understanding market demands.

- What was your path to the profession of designer and this job?

- I'm self-taught. He began to work in this direction more than 10 years ago. Then there were no such educational projects that are now, especially in absentia. Maybe there was something in Moscow, but then I lived in Astrakhan. There, reality was a little divorced from the world. The Internet, of course, was. And so he fascinated me greatly.
It seemed very cool to me that on the Internet you can get so much information, tell your stories to people from all over the world.
I began to study exactly how the information lives on the Internet. So I came to the interface solutions - sites.
At the same time, I was organizing events and had to understand advertising: know how to stand out from others, find an audience. So I began to immerse myself in various graphic aspects and mechanisms for attracting attention. In fact, I took what was done before me, and adapted it to the solution of my problem. It is important to avoid a blank sheet and be able to work with references. Much has already been invented for us.
Then I went to the Netology course in web design. It was designed for beginners, so I knew more than I gave this course. He began to help with the development of this educational branch. It took me 4.5 years to become a director. As you can see, I started as a student and went through all the stages.
‚ÄúDesign requires empathy. You create a product for people, therefore you should be able to immerse yourself in their problems and context ‚Äù

- What skills, not directly related to design, every day help you in your work?

‚ÄúWild curiosity and love for what I do helped me.‚Äù I am convinced that it‚Äôs impossible to do well what you don‚Äôt like and dig deep where it‚Äôs not interesting. More sociability. I am an open person, do not hesitate to start a conversation, you can always come up to me and talk.
Design is an area that requires a lot of empathy. You create a product for people, so you should feel good about them. There are no good and bad people; there is a context that affects us. Designers should understand this almost at the level of a psychologist.




- What is more important for the success of the designer: narrow specialization and honed skill in one field or universal skills? Talent or experience?

- Now there are practically no narrow directions; there are decompositions of large product branches. But a modern designer is a dude who lives in the whole realm. Some people come to design and think that they‚Äôll now learn how to make landings on Tilda and start making big money. But in fact, this is only the beginning. You need to learn how to work with business and understand: you are working for the result.
The designer, after all, is working on a lot of internal issues in order to come to the external component. Even when choosing milk in a supermarket, we first read how different packs look. We take the one that we like, and only then look at how much it costs, what composition. What we do not like externally, we most likely will not even pick up.
The designer should thoroughly research the field of work, understand what his users will pay attention to, and draw up the correct path map.
I do not believe in talent. It is too dependent on the environment and the forces that your parents invested in you in childhood. In adulthood it is harder to master something. In the head, the lazy monkey first turns on and only then the rational personality. The main thing is to start. And in as simple a language as possible explain the current task to the lazy monkey in his head. When it starts to work out, something will click and even your lazy part will start to get high. But not everyone reaches this stage.

- Is it necessary to be a creative person to become a good designer?

- It‚Äôs better not to be creative at all in order to become a good designer. The designer is primarily a designer, and the creative act is more for a sense of beauty. Creative people all the time go to an artist who shares his inner world. And the designer is a different story. He works as part of a business task.
To become a good designer, you need to equate creativity with a custom result. It is important to have a good taste and find creative ways to solve problems. And all this can be honed. For example, look at the work of other designers or read a book and visualize images. You need to approach everything from the perspective of analysis: why it is done exactly like that, what is the meaning of this and how it helps people.




- How easy is it to switch from one design profession to another? For example, starting as a web designer, moving to UX design, and then creating packaging and advertising layouts for FMCG brands?

- You can switch from one profession to another. The question, rather, is how to develop: vertically or horizontally. You need to strive to be a pro in your niche and understand the neighboring ones well. The basis of any direction is one goal - designing user experience and its visualization. For graphic designers, this image lives in the world of marketing. For groceries - in the world of business. Motion lives in the video, and game design in the gaming realm. You need to understand that if you are a cool motion designer, but you hate computer games, you are unlikely to become a cool game designer.
But designers often need to take tools from neighboring areas. For example, a product designer understands that it is not surprising to surprise his users with a static image, and goes to 3D and motion, takes something for his product. In any case, the longer you are in design, the more areas you have time to touch.

- Without which it is impossible to imagine your workplace? What gadgets do you need?

- Need a laptop with a good matrix. If you have money, you can buy software for work. No - not scary, there are free solutions. The rest is a matter of convenience for each person. Some need a mouse, others like to work on a tablet, while others require a giant monitor or keyboard of a special color.

- How is the ASUS VivoBook S15 qualitatively different from your previous laptop? For you, as a designer, is its appearance important?

- It is lightweight, it is convenient to carry it everywhere with you. At the same time, he closes the basic tasks of creating interfaces. Good screen quality, responsive and convenient trackpad, the operating system is fast - there is enough memory. Oh, and he also has an important price advantage. Within this budget, he has a good ratio of parameters, without an obvious overpayment for the brand.
Appearance is important in part. Not so much color as texture. For example, I need the laptop to be pleasant to the touch: less glossy, more matte, roughened. And so that the keyboard does not infuriate me with the complexity of reading. The Asus keyboard has a good stroke and readability. I would have made it darker.




- There is an opinion that laptops for designers are always a compromise between a large display and portability, performance and size. What, from this point of view, is the ASUS VivoBook S15?

- Each has its own diagonal comfort zone. I can safely work on a laptop. For me, a super-comfortable diagonal is 15 inches. If there is any big task that requires accuracy and concentration, it is better to connect a monitor. A laptop is more a story about the fact that you can work anywhere and carry it with you.
I have no complaints about the display of the ASUS VivoBook S15. He has a good matrix and indicators, his hvIt is suitable for solving most basic design tasks without going into history, where delicate work with color is needed. Especially when you consider the budget cost - this is a very good ratio of price and quality.

- For many designers, the mouse is a more convenient tool than the touchpad. What do you usually use? And how convenient was working with the ScreenPad 2.0 smart touchpad?

- I try to work with the touchpad. I don‚Äôt like to carry a mouse with me. I usually connect it for finer work, where the touchpad will not be so convenient to use. Plus, the touchpad has its own pluses: quick page folding, hot keys. For managerial work it is enough. I attract a mouse for more serious tasks.
ScreenPad 2.0 is a good idea, something fresh in the mass market. It allows you to quickly switch to other tasks or launch a messenger window where you will not answer, but you need to see what is being discussed. It's cool.

See what the VivoBook S15 can do




‚ÄúThe final result and the number of edits should be discussed in advance‚Äù

- How does a good designer react to client edits? When can and should I insist on my own?

- First of all, you need to understand one thing: you are a designer from a large company or a freelancer.
The designer from the company knows the business and understands what a visual solution will lead him to. He must be able to justify why it is necessary to do exactly what it will bring to the company. Freelancer works with business. Often, he does not have time to understand all the intricacies of the company. Therefore, it may be useful for him to listen to a client who knows this business better. If the decision is refused, it is necessary to discuss and explain why it would be preferable to do just that.
If you allow yourself to push through and question your skills as a specialist - this is bad.
One option - you did a project on your knee, thought you had a ride, but no. Second - this client is just too tough for you. A good designer should discuss in advance the number of edits and the final result. One must always seek a communication compromise. The business gave comments that you did not like, but after them the customer was satisfied. So you covered his need, and for this he hired you.




- What advice, proven by personal experience, could you give to beginners in design, dreaming of a cool portfolio, but not having cool customers yet?

- It is very simple. If there are no customers, you do not need to spend 100% of the time searching for them. You go to any well-known site and rebrand the selected product. You describe your approach, see and post, for example, on Behance. Such things can work better than a real case. They can run a sundress, and everyone in the community will say that some newcomer has swung at rebranding Mercedes.
It is necessary to develop a personal brand. You can tell for a long time in the area that you are a designer, but if Google does not know your name, then it seems that you do not exist. You need to find a social network where people from your sphere hang out and engage in self-management. Your account on social networks is how many people will know you. They can know a fun guy from parties, and they can know a professional. You need to go to designer parties, get acquainted, shovel the Internet, and most importantly - do not wait, but do it.



ASUS VivoBook S15 is a lightweight laptop with an original design. It is suitable for those who like bright and stylish equipment and want to be able to conveniently work from anywhere. The ASUS VivoBook S15 has an additional functional screen - the touchpad TouchPad 2.0. It allows you to run different applications and work in multitasking mode. Reasonably priced model.
